case_name: Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1966 and Criminal Appeal No. 238 of 1966

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the order dated August 5, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1020 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the order dated August 5, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1020 of 966,

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 238 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 40 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: AND Criminal Appeal No. 238 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revi- sion No. 40 of 1965.

facts.text: Respondent Dinesh Mishra lodged a first information report on June 3, 1965 at Rajoun Police Station that he saw a thatched house of Uma Kant Misra burning and petitioners running away.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1966, the respondent, Dinesh Mishra, lodged a first information report, on June 3, 1965, at the Rajoun Police Station, that he saw a thatched house, of one Uma Kant Misra, situated on the numberthern side of his house, burning, and the petitioners herein., running away from the scene,.

facts.text: Police investigated and submitted a final report under S.173 CrPC on July 13, 1965 stating the offence complained of was false.

anchor.surface_text: The police made an investigation and submitted what is called a final report, under s. 173  1  of the Code, to the effect that the offence companyplained of, was false. The Sub-Divisional Magistrate received this report on July 13, 1965,

facts.text: Respondent filed a protest petition challenging the correctness of the police final report.

anchor.surface_text: but, in the meanwhile, the respondent had filed what is termed a protest petition, challenging the companyrectness of the report submitted by the police.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate on October 27, 1965 directed police to submit charge-sheet against petitioners after perusing police diary and hearing counsel.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate appears to have perused the police diary and, after hearing the companynsel for the respondent and the public prosecutor, passed an order on October 27, 1965, directing the police to submit a charge-sheet, against the petitioners, herein.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged the Magistrate's order before Sessions Judge Bhagalpur without success.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners challenged this order, without success, both before the learned Sessions Judge, Bhagalpur,

facts.text: Patna High Court upheld the Magistrate's order on August 5, 1966 in Cr Rev No. 1020/1966.

anchor.surface_text: and the Patna High Court. It was held by the High Court, following its previous decision, that the Magistrate has jurisdiction to call for a charge-sheet, when he disagrees with the report submitted by the police, under S. 173 1  of the Code.

facts.text: Second respondent lodged written report on February 24, 1964 at Malsalami police station that daughter Hiramani missing from February 21, 1964 and appellants kidnapped her.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Criminal Appeal No. 238 of 1966, the second respondent therein, had lodged a written report, on February 24. 1.964, before the police, at Malsalami police station, that his daughter, Hiramani, was missing from February 21, 1964, and that the appellants in that appeal, had kidnapped her.

facts.text: Case under S.366 IPC registered against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: A case under S. 366 I.P.C. was registered against them.

facts.text: Police submitted final report stating girl recovered and she eloped of her own accord.

anchor.surface_text: The police, after investigation, submitted a final report to the Magistrate. to the effect that the girl companycerned, had been recovered and that she bad stated that she had, of her own accord, eloped and therefore the police stated that the case might be treated as closed.

facts.text: Second respondent filed protest petition and complaint under S.498 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent filed a protest petition in Court, challenging the statements of the police and he also filed a companyplaint, under s. 498 I.P.C.

facts.text: Magistrate directed investigating officer to submit charge-sheet under S.366 IPC against accused.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, after a perusal of the case diary of the police, and hearing the lawyer for the appellants and the second respondent, as also the public prosecutor, passed an order directing the investigating officer to submit a charge-sheet, against the accused persons, under S. 366 I.P.C

facts.text: Sessions Judge and Patna High Court confirmed the Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: This order has been companyfirmed by the, learned Sessions Judge, as well as the Patna High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Magistrate has no power to direct police to submit charge-sheet after final report under S.173 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, to companyclude, there is numberpower, expressly or im- pliedly companyferred, under the Code, on a Magistrate to call upon the police to submit a charge-sheet, when they have sent a report under s. 169 of the Code, that there is numbercase made out for sending tip an accused for trial.

facts.text: Magistrate can direct further investigation under S.156(3) if final report unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: That is, if the Magistrate feels, after companysidering the final report, that the investigation is unsatisfactory, or incomplete, or that there is scope for further investigation, it will be open to the Magistrate to decline to accept the final report and direct the police to make further investigation, under s. 1 5 6   3  .

facts.text: Magistrate can take cognizance under S.190(1)(c) notwithstanding police final report.

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, if he still suspects that an offence has been companymitted, he is entitled, numberwithstanding the opinion of tile police, to take companynizance, under S. 190 1  c  of the Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Magistrate's orders directing charge-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, subject to the directions companytained above, the orders of the Magistrate, directing the police to file charge, will be set aside, and the appeals allowed, to that extent.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows Magistrate to treat protest petitions as complaints and proceed accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, while holding that the orders of the Magistrate, in each of these cases, directing the police to file charge-sheets, is Without jurisdiction, we make it clear that it is open to the Magistrate to treat the respective protest petitions, as companyplaints,

facts.text: There is conflict of opinion between High Courts on Magistrate's power to direct charge-sheet after police final report.

anchor.surface_text: The companymon question, that arises for company- sideration, in these two criminal appeals, by special leave, is as to whether a Magistrate can direct the police to submit a charge-sheet, when the police, after the investigation into a companygnizable offence, had submitted a final report, under S. 173 of the Code of. Criminal Procedure  hereinafter called the Code . There is a companyflict of opinion, on this point between the various High Courts in India.

facts.text: Girl Hiramani stated she eloped of her own accord and is above 19 years old.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel pointed out that the police report before the Magistrate clearly shows that the girl, in question, who is stated to be above 19 years of age, has herself stated that she bad eloped, of her own accord
Appeal by special leave from the order dated August 5, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1020 of 966, AND Criminal Appeal No. 238 of 1966.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revi- sion No. 40 of 1965. P. Jha and Subhag Mal Jain, for the appellants  in Cr. No. 218 of 1966 .

The common question, that arises for company- sideration, in these two criminal appeals, by special leave, is as to whether a Magistrate can direct the police to submit a charge-sheet, when the police, after the investigation into a companygnizable offence, had submitted a final report, under S. 173 of the Code of. Criminal Procedure  hereinafter called the Code . There is a companyflict of opinion, on this point between the various High Courts in India.

anchor.surface_text: Just as it is essential that every one accused of a crime should have free access to a court of justice so that he may be duly acquitted if found not guilty of the offence with which he is charged, so it is, of the utmost importance that the judiciary should not interfere with the police in matters which are within their province and into which the law imposes on them the duty of inquiry.

concepts.interpretation: Judiciary must not interfere with statutory police investigation rights except in specific cases like habeas corpus.

issues.text: whether a Magistrate can direct the police to submit a charge-sheet, when the police, after the investigation into a companygnizable offence, had submitted a final report, under S. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: is as to whether a Magistrate can direct the police to submit a charge-sheet, when the police, after the investigation into a companygnizable offence, had submitted a final report, under S. 173 of the Code of. Criminal Procedure  hereinafter called the Code . There is a companyflict of opinion, on this point between the various High Courts in India.

issues.text: the question as to whether the Magistrate has got power to direct the police to file a charge-sheet, on receipt of a report under s. 173

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the Magistrate has got power to direct the police to file a charge-sheet, on receipt of a report under s. 173 really depends upon the nature of the jurisdiction exercised by a Magistrate, on receiving a report. In this connection, we may refer to certain observations, made by the Judicial Committee in King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmed

issues.text: can [the Magistrate] differ from the police and call upon them to submit a final report, under s.169

anchor.surface_text: The question can also be considered from another point of view. Supposing the police send a report, viz., a charge- sheet, under s. 170 of the Code. As we have already pointed out, the Magistrate is not bound to accept that report, when he considers the matter judicially. But, can he differ from the police. and call upon them to submit a final report, under s.169 ?

issues.text: whether the Magistrate can direct further investigation under s.156(3) if the final report indicates unsatisfactory or incomplete investigation

anchor.surface_text: That is, if the Magistrate feels, after considering the final report, that the investigation is unsatisfactory, or incomplete, or that there is scope for further investigation, it will be open to the Magistrate to decline to accept the final report and direct the police to make further investigation, under s. 156 (3) .

issues.text: whether the Magistrate can take cognizance under s.190(1)(c) notwithstanding the police final report

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, if he still suspects that an offence has been committed, he is entitled, notwithstanding the opinion of tile police, to take cognizance, under S. 190 1 c of the Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: Magistrate can direct further investigation under S.156(3) or take cognizance under S.190(1)(c)

arguments.claim: Scheme of Chapter XIV indicates formation of opinion on whether case to place accused on trial is that of investigating officers; Magistrate cannot compel police to form particular opinion

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the High Court, following its previous decision, that the Magistrate has jurisdiction to call for a charge-sheet, when he disagrees with the report submitted by the police, under S. 173 1  of the Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: No power under Code to direct charge-sheet after final report

arguments.claim: Formation of opinion whether case to place accused on trial is that of police officer in charge; judiciary should not interfere with police investigation

anchor.surface_text: Just as it is essential that every one accused of a crime should have free access to a court of justice so that he may be duly acquitted if found not guilty of the offence with which he is charged, so it is, of the utmost importance that the judiciary should not interfere with the police in matters which are within their province

arguments.claim: No express provision empowering Magistrate to direct charge-sheet; such power cannot be inferred from scheme of Chapter XIV

anchor.surface_text: The High Courts which have held that the Magistrate has no jurisdiction to call upon the police to file a charge-sheet, under such circumstances, have rested their decision on two principles viz.,  a  that there is no express provision in the Code empowering a Magistrate to pass such an order and  b  such a power, in view of the scheme of Chapter XIV, cannot be inferred

arguments.claim: Magistrate can direct further investigation under S.156(3) if final report shows unsatisfactory or incomplete investigation

anchor.surface_text: That is, if the Magistrate feels, after considering the final report, that the investigation is unsatisfactory, or incomplete, or that there is scope for further investigation, it will be open to the Magistrate to decline to accept the final report and direct the police to make further investigation, under s. 156 (3) .

arguments.claim: Magistrate can take cognizance under S.190(1)(c) notwithstanding police final report if suspects offence committed

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, if he still suspects that an offence has been committed, he is entitled, notwithstanding the opinion of tile police, to take cognizance, under S. 190 1  c  of the Code.

arguments.claim: Magistrate cannot compel police to change opinion and submit charge-sheet; encroaches on police sphere

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate cannot compel the police to form a particular opinion, on the investigation, and to submit a report, according to such opinion. That will be really encroaching on the sphere of the police and compelling the police to form an opinion so as to accord with the decision of the Magistrate

arguments.claim: Magistrate has no power to direct police to submit final report under S.169 if they submitted charge-sheet under S.170

anchor.surface_text: Supposing the police send a report, viz., a charge- sheet, under s. 170 of the Code. As we have already pointed out, the Magistrate is not bound to accept that report, when he considers the matter judicially. But, can he differ from the police. and call upon them to submit a final report, under s.169 ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Symmetry in powers; no power either way

arguments.claim: Further proceedings unnecessary in appeal 238 as girl above 19 eloped voluntarily per police report

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rect further proceedings to be companytinued, so far as his clients are companycerned. Learned companynsel pointed out that the police report before t

arguments.court_reasoning: Whether offence made out not to be considered at this stage

holdings.text: There is no power, expressly or impliedly conferred, under the Code, on a Magistrate to call upon the police to submit a charge-sheet, when they have sent a report under s. 169 of the Code, that there is no case made out for sending an accused for trial.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, to conclude, there is no power, expressly or im- pliedly conferred, under the Code, on a Magistrate to call upon the police to submit a charge-sheet, when they have sent a report under s. 169 of the Code, that there is no case made out for sending tip an accused for trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express provision; scheme of Chapter XIV vests opinion formation on sufficiency of evidence solely with police; confirmed by precedents like Nazir Ahmed and Rishbud.

holdings.text: If the Magistrate feels, after considering the final report, that the investigation is unsatisfactory, or incomplete, or that there is scope for further investigation, it will be open to the Magistrate to decline to accept the final report and direct the police to make further investigation, under s. 156(3).

anchor.surface_text: That is, if the Magistrate feels, after considering the final report, that the investigation is unsatisfactory, or incomplete, or that there is scope for further investigation, it will be open to the Magistrate to decline to accept the final report and direct the police to make further investigation, under s. 1 5 6   3  .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power under s.156(3) allows direction for further probe if initial investigation inadequate, preserving Magistrate's oversight without usurping police discretion.

holdings.text: If he still suspects that an offence has been committed, he is entitled, notwithstanding the opinion of the police, to take cognizance, under S. 190(1)(c) of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, if he still suspects that an offence has been committed, he is entitled, notwithstanding the opinion of tile police, to take cognizance, under S. 190 1  c  of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.190(1)(c) empowers Magistrate to act on own suspicion or information independent of police report, ensuring offences not go unpunished.

holdings.text: The Magistrate has no power to direct the police to submit a final report under s.169 if they have submitted a charge-sheet under s.170.

anchor.surface_text: Supposing the police send a report, viz., a charge- sheet, under s. 170 of the Code. As we have already pointed out, the Magistrate is not bound to accept that report, when he considers the matter judicially. But, can he differ from the police. and call upon them to submit a final report, under s.169 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symmetry in statutory scheme; police form binding opinion on evidence sufficiency, Magistrate cannot compel contrary report.

holdings.text: It is open to the Magistrate to treat the respective protest petitions, as complaints, and take further proceedings, according to law.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, while holding that the orders of the Magistrate, in each of these cases, directing the police to file charge-sheets, is Without jurisdiction, we make it clear that it is open to the Magistrate to treat the respective protest petitions, as complaints,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Protest petitions challenge police report; treatable as complaints under s.190(1)(a) for cognizance without directing police.

holdings.text: The orders of the Magistrate, directing the police to file charge-sheets, are without jurisdiction and are set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, subject to the directions contained above, the orders of the Magistrate, directing the police to file charge, will be set aside, and the appeals allowed, to that extent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holding h1 to facts of both appeals; no jurisdiction exists.

holdings.text: Whether an offence is made out or whether any of the appellants are guilty are matters which do not require to be considered by this Court at this stage.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel pointed out that the police report before the Magistrate clearly shows that the girl, in question, who is stated to be above 19 years of age, has herself stated that she bad eloped, of her own accord

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interlocutory stage; merits not for Supreme Court review now.

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmed 1

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmed 1

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v Khwaja Nazir Ahmed
precedents.cited_proposition: Judiciary should not interfere with statutory right of police to investigate cognizable offences
precedents.cited_holding: Just as it is essential that every one accused of a crime should have free access to a court of justice so that he may be duly acquitted if found not guilty of the offence with which he is charged, so it is, of the utmost importance that the judiciary should not interfere with the police in matters which are within their province and into which the law imposes on them the duty of inquiry.

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 2

precedents.case_name: H N Rishbud v State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Formation of opinion as to whether there is a case to place accused on trial is that of the police officer
precedents.cited_holding: the final step in the investigation viz., the formation of the opinion as to whether or not there is a case to place the accused on trial is to be that of the officer in-charge of the police station.

anchor.surface_text: Supposing the police send a report, viz., a charge- sheet, under s. 170 of the Code. As we have already pointed out, the Magistrate is not bound to accept that report, when he considers the matter judicially. But, can he differ from the police. and call upon them to submit a final report, under s.169 ?
In the result, subject to the directions contained above, the orders of the Magistrate, directing the police to file a charge, will be set aside, and the appeals allowed, to that extent.
